Sentence: Quote: Originally Posted by thugnegro hey guys im currently looking for and upgrade of my system .  but i cant decide which one to go for .  A used Klipsch High-End 5.1 Speaker System a guy is selling me or a new Pioneer SP-PK21BS .  the Klipsch High-End 5.1 Speaker System has: 2-Klipsch RF-15 Reference Series 2-Klipsch RS-25 Rear Speakers 1-Klipsch RC-25 Reference Series Center 1-Klipsch RPW-10 Reference Series All of this for 250 the Pioneer SP-PK21BS .  is 399 i know the Klipsch are a lil old and the pioneer are gonna be new .  So i just wanna know even when the Klipsch are old would it be a smart to buy them at that price?  or woul it be better to go for the pioneer?  Unless the speakers are damaged I would pay $250 for the Klipsch because that sounds like a really good deal, but fwiw, that isn't considered a Klipsch " High end system. " Later on if you wanted to upgrade your mains to a Klipsch high end system you could use some of those other speakers in the mix .  Good Luck and welcome to the forum.

Okay, I figured it out already!  Man this is a great motherboard!  nForce 680i sucks and I will never use it again .  I have to say, even the 590i Chipset was better compared to the 680i Series lol

I decided to leave Time Warner Cable and go with Dish .  I have the Dish on the house but the technician couldn't get it to work with my home entertainment system .  Time Warner allows their DVR to connect to the AV receiver by HDMI but not Dish .  With Dish I need to hook the TV directly to the Dish DVR and use RCA cables for sound instead of HDMI .  My concern is that I will loose sound quality .  Here is what I have: TV is a Pioneer Elite Pro-141FD AV Receiver is a Pioneer SC-25 Blu Ray Player LG BD390 Here is how I might have to hook it up .  Two HDMI from the TV, one to the DVR and one to the AV Receiver .  Then, RCA cables to the DVR for sound .  HDMI cable from the receiver to the Blu Ray .  Is there a better way to hook this up?  Thanks,

Quote: Originally Posted by mastiff34 Got off the phone with Denon, here's is what they said encase anyone else has similiar issues in the future .  They indicated when using a receiver the range for an hdmi signal is about 15 - 20' and the reason why the PS3 works when dropping out deep color is because of the decreased bandwidth, which I believe someone else mentioned on here as well .  To finally troubleshoot, they gave me two things to try tonight, one was to lower the resolution (which I tried and it didn't work for the HTPC based on someones suggestion here), the second is to remove the 20' run from the equation and hook it up to another display and see if I have the sparkles .  If I do, then it's a faulty receiver if I don't then it's the run and I need an HDMI booster .  I'm using a Denon AVR-3311 with an 25 ft .  Monoprice 22 AWG HDMI cable (5 years old and before there were 'high speed " rated HDMI cables) from my AVR to a ceiling HDMI outlet .  I then run a 6 ft .  Monoprice 28 AWG high speed rated HDMI cable from the ceiling outlet to my RS40 projector .  I have not had issues with this setup for either 2D or 3D .  2D video using 1080p/60 with deep color turned on can actually require more bandwidth for the HDMI transmission than for frame packed 1080p/24 used for 3D video .  Perhaps there is an issue with your specific 20 ft .  HDMI cable .  If the problem is your cable (rather than your AVR) then either an HDMI Amplifier or a replacement 20 ft HDMI High Speed Cable are your options .  If you attempt to do some testing by connecting another TV (I assume it would be a 2D HDTV) to the AVR's HDMI output, then that HDTV would need to support 1080p/60 input with deep color in order verify the AVR is actually correctly passing the most demanding (highest bandwidth) signal.

Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech I tried to record off a Motorola 6400 that said the firewire was " enabled=yes ", " active=no " That's the expected status .  It'll work, provided that the DVHS VCR is tuned to the correct input (D-1, or D-2, or D-3, etc) and the 5c flag isn't set to Copy-Once or Copy-Never .  (PC's and the Mits DVHS VCRs can't record Copy-Once material) active=no just means that it wasn't in use at that moment .  Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech I followed the instructions for the 2000U and made a test recording onto D-VHS .  But when I tried to play it back through the T165, there was nothing .  Comcast has since replaced that box with a Pace model RGN-110 box.. . tried to record off it and it didn't work .  There's any number of mistakes that could have occurred here.. .You need to monitor the output of the firewire in realtime, to make sure that the DVHS is getting anything at all .  Have one firewire cable going from the cable box to the DVHS VCR, and another firewire cable going from the DVHS VCR to the T165 .  Connect the T165 to your TV (tune the T165 to view the DVHS).  This will let you know if a signal is reaching the DVHS .  Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech Some guys also told me the Mitsubishi won't work with a firewire cable boxes .  I've used the Mits 1100u quite a few times with my Motorola DCH3416 .  I can't recall if I've tried to use my Mits 2000u with my cable box, but I'd be really surprised if it didn't also work flawlessly (I'll try to run a test in the next day or so).  The Mits DVHS VCR's are not 5c compliant, so you can only record material which is flagged Copy-Freely .  The JVC DVHS VCR's are 5c compliant and let you record anything flagged Copy-Freely or Copy-Once.

Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech I tried to record off a Motorola 6400 that said the firewire was " enabled=yes ", " active=no " That's the expected status .  It'll work, provided that the DVHS VCR is tuned to the correct input (D-1, or D-2, or D-3, etc) and the 5c flag isn't set to Copy-Once or Copy-Never .  (PC's and the Mits DVHS VCRs can't record Copy-Once material) active=no just means that it wasn't in use at that moment .  Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech I followed the instructions for the 2000U and made a test recording onto D-VHS .  But when I tried to play it back through the T165, there was nothing .  Comcast has since replaced that box with a Pace model RGN-110 box.. . tried to record off it and it didn't work .  There's any number of mistakes that could have occurred here.. .You need to monitor the output of the firewire in realtime, to make sure that the DVHS is getting anything at all .  Have one firewire cable going from the cable box to the DVHS VCR, and another firewire cable going from the DVHS VCR to the T165 .  Connect the T165 to your TV (tune the T165 to view the DVHS).  This will let you know if a signal is reaching the DVHS .  Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech Some guys also told me the Mitsubishi won't work with a firewire cable boxes .  I've used the Mits 1100u quite a few times with my Motorola DCH3416 .  I can't recall if I've tried to use my Mits 2000u with my cable box, but I'd be really surprised if it didn't also work flawlessly (I'll try to run a test in the next day or so).  The Mits DVHS VCR's are not 5c compliant, so you can only record material which is flagged Copy-Freely .  The JVC DVHS VCR's are 5c compliant and let you record anything flagged Copy-Freely or Copy-Once.

The ONLY thing I'm using a VCR for now is to copy tapes over to my PC, where I will burn them to DVD (Doing Star Wars Episode 4 right now.) My PC has a Hauppage WinPVR250 that does real-time MPEG encoding .  I use that to record (what doesn't get recorded on the DVR510 - sometimes I will record from the 510).

I've got all my music on a linkstation NAS drive attached to my wireless router .  I've got a rather snazzy Denon networked and wireless stero as a gift for my 40th, but we also use an old X box (green one) and various ipods and docks round the house and it gives a decent enough flexible part wireless, part docked coverage all over .  I have an app on my IPOD touch (Plugplayer) that allows me to stream to it or other devices, so effectively an remote control.

Quote: Originally Posted by sparks81 My mistake .  As this is my first time on this thread, I was not aware of these problems. I worked for a dealer that sold the Pioneer and I was never aware of these problems described above .  I also have the BDP-94HD in another system .  No problems with either one except for the firmware updates .  It sounds like Pioneer has resolved these problems.. .hopefully!  have you used the analog outs yet?  If so, what do you think?  I have mine connected both ways to a Theta Digital Cassablanca III .  Analog sounds OK .  But, the digital connection reigns supreme.. .since the DACs in the Theta out perform the Wolfson DACs in the BDP-09 .  The 09 nonetheless, is still a good player .  The BDP-09FD's drive failures seemed to show up for everybody just around the 24 month mark as the 2 year Elite warranty expired.. .. .. I've got my BDP-09FD connected to a Pioneer VSX-59TXi receiver via analogs and think the 09FD is great for decoding the Blu-ray HD audio formats .  I don't use the 09 for music, I use my Pioneer DV-59AVi DVD player for music via the 59AVi's iLink connection to the 59TXi .  I just personally think the digital iLink connection sounds more dynamic and robust than the 09's analog for CDs and the 09 does not play SACD and DVD-Audio discs .  I really like the 09FD as a DVD player and think it may be the best DVD player I've ever seen .  The 59TXi has enough power to compensate for the volume loss from using analog inputs .  It's really weird how great the 09 sounds for movie and concert BDs but doesn't for CDs, maybe I am just spoiled by the 59AVi on music.. . Fred

Wanted to say thanks for the fantastic guide and have enjoyed all of the great information from this community .  I have built a couple Frankenstein htpc machines from old salvaged parts from my work, but this will be the first dedicated HTPC machine .  Please let me know how these specs look for a family room HTPC (WAF & DAF very important): Case: Habey EMC-600B Optical: None - Everything is on the NAS and use network quad core for ripping/transcoding Mobo: ASRock H67M-ITX LGA 1155 Intel H67 N82E16813157238 CPU: I3 2100 Boot Hd: OCZ Solid 3 60GB Secondary Hd: 250gb 2.5 hd (salvage) I have 5tb on the NAS so just wanted a little more than the boot os local .  Memory: 2gb 1066 (salvage) I know this is low, but I already have it, plus with a fast SSD you don't pay that much of a penalty for page file swapping .  Is this ok, or should I spend the $25 and go for 4gb 1333?  Cable: Networked bridged Ceton infitivi4 2 channels - 1gb lan Remote: This is one of my biggest concerns, suggestions appreciated .  On my basement HTPC I am using/testing 4 remotes: Harmony SST-659 best for turning on/off TV/Receiver/htpc, only so so for WMC navigation .  Lenovo N5902 maybe best all around but still lacking for control of other devices and quick access to forward/reverse, ease of use when not staring at remote .  Not good for speed watching of football games .  Iphone - logitech touch mouse best for keyboard entry and mouse based navigation, poor for WMC control .  Iphone Boxee remote control - great for boxee no use for wmc .  VRC-1100 bad for text entry, tivo remote type shape and layout probably make it best for overall wmc navigation .  IR seems very sensitive about aiming directly at sensor .  This will primarily be for watching TV, NAS movie library, netflix and hulu .  Not a fan of home 3D - yet.

AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked by VR-Zone.com VR-Zone FORUMS PRICEWATCH VIDEOS CHINESE AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked Reported by Sub on Thursday, December 15 2011 4:17 am A slide purportedly to be part of the press deck, detailing Radeon HD 7970, has leaked online .  As previously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture with 32 CUs .  Tweet NEWS A slide purportedly detailing Radeon HD 7970 has leaked online .  The slide resembles AMD's standard presentation design, and is seemingly part of the press deck held .  Aspreviously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture .  The HD 7970 features 32 CU containing 2048 ALUs, clocked at 925 MHz .  This amounts to 3.5 TFLOPS (Single Precision).  TMUs are upped to 128, as expected .  However, ROPs remain at 32 compared to Cayman, which is odd considering the memory bus, as we have observed, is 384-bit .  Memory speed remains unchanged at 5.5 GHz, meaning a 50% boost in memory bandwidth .  The TDP is rated under 300W, while the idle power is incredibly only 3W .  This means a 8-pin + 6-pin power connector configuration .  HD 7970 features 4 display outs - 1x DVI, 2xmini-DisplayPort and 1x HDMI .  Finally, the slide mentions the embargo release date - 9th January 2012 .  Needless to say, faked slides are nothing new for the rumour mill, so the information contained within this slide must be considered with caution .  However, most of the details contained are realistic, and the image of the shroud looks identical to the leaked pictures . Quote: Originally Posted by MichaelLAX I have two DirecTiVo HD HR10-250s and two DirecTV HD HR20-700s .  I find the situation of recording from the newer HR20-700 even better than the older model .  In the older model, you had to manually change the resolution to 480i so that you could get a video signal out of the S-Video port, and then you manually had to change it back to 1080i to watch it in that resolution on your HDTV after recording .  Now the HR20-700 outputs a video signal from all of the Video ports even when the HDMI is sending 1080i to the HDTV .  I find that the video signal is anamorphic either when I record it to my Panny VHS/DVD Recorder (although I have to record it on a DVD-RW and use my computer to fix the aspect ratio setting on the resulting DVD-R) and on my ADS Tech Instant DVD (for Mac) MPEG-2 digitizer box (which I use when I want to edit down the resulting digitized content before I burn it to a DVD or convert it to H.264 for my Apple TV).  I am very happy now that I can DVD record (or digitize) all of the new 16x9 HD channels that DirecTV has to offer.. . Good luck!  Thanks for your reply .  I like the fact that you don't have to change the resolution .  You said: " I find that the video signal is anamorphic either when I record it to my Panny VHS/DVD Recorder (although I have to record it on a DVD-RW and use my computer to fix the aspect ratio setting on the resulting DVD-R) " .  I assume that you use ifoedit or something similar to change the aspect flags from 4:3 to 16:9 .  I also have a Panasonic DVD/HD recorder for which I have to do the same thing .  The nice thing about the two Sony DVD recorders I listed is that you don't have to do that .  Anyone on the forum burning DVDs from the HR20 or HR21 to the Sony DVD recorders I listed?

Quote: Originally Posted by MichaelLAX I have two DirecTiVo HD HR10-250s and two DirecTV HD HR20-700s .  I find the situation of recording from the newer HR20-700 even better than the older model .  In the older model, you had to manually change the resolution to 480i so that you could get a video signal out of the S-Video port, and then you manually had to change it back to 1080i to watch it in that resolution on your HDTV after recording .  Now the HR20-700 outputs a video signal from all of the Video ports even when the HDMI is sending 1080i to the HDTV .  I find that the video signal is anamorphic either when I record it to my Panny VHS/DVD Recorder (although I have to record it on a DVD-RW and use my computer to fix the aspect ratio setting on the resulting DVD-R) and on my ADS Tech Instant DVD (for Mac) MPEG-2 digitizer box (which I use when I want to edit down the resulting digitized content before I burn it to a DVD or convert it to H.264 for my Apple TV).  I am very happy now that I can DVD record (or digitize) all of the new 16x9 HD channels that DirecTV has to offer.. . Good luck!  Thanks for your reply .  I like the fact that you don't have to change the resolution .  You said: " I find that the video signal is anamorphic either when I record it to my Panny VHS/DVD Recorder (although I have to record it on a DVD-RW and use my computer to fix the aspect ratio setting on the resulting DVD-R) " .  I assume that you use ifoedit or something similar to change the aspect flags from 4:3 to 16:9 .  I also have a Panasonic DVD/HD recorder for which I have to do the same thing .  The nice thing about the two Sony DVD recorders I listed is that you don't have to do that .  Anyone on the forum burning DVDs from the HR20 or HR21 to the Sony DVD recorders I listed?

eSATA Doesn't Work!  Ok, Im at an impasse and I think Ive tried everything, so please someone come up with something new to help me!  I have a brand new HR21-700 running 0x1FE .  I read all the threads about this and I installed a WD10EACS into an Antec MX-1 VERIS enclosure .  Ive tried both the eSATA cable that came with the enclosure and a separately purchased SIIG eSATA cable .  Ive switched the cable ends .  Ive tried I think every variation of starting up  power off HR21, power on external for five minutes, then power up the HR21, a simple red button reboot and all the I can think of variations in between but no love .  It just boots off the internal every time .  Any ideas?

Sentence: AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked by VR-Zone.com VR-Zone FORUMS PRICEWATCH VIDEOS CHINESE AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked Reported by Sub on Thursday, December 15 2011 4:17 am A slide purportedly to be part of the press deck, detailing Radeon HD 7970, has leaked online .  As previously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture with 32 CUs .  Tweet NEWS A slide purportedly detailing Radeon HD 7970 has leaked online .  The slide resembles AMD's standard presentation design, and is seemingly part of the press deck held .  Aspreviously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture .  The HD 7970 features 32 CU containing 2048 ALUs, clocked at 925 MHz .  This amounts to 3.5 TFLOPS (Single Precision).  TMUs are upped to 128, as expected .  However, ROPs remain at 32 compared to Cayman, which is odd considering the memory bus, as we have observed, is 384-bit .  Memory speed remains unchanged at 5.5 GHz, meaning a 50% boost in memory bandwidth .  The TDP is rated under 300W, while the idle power is incredibly only 3W .  This means a 8-pin + 6-pin power connector configuration .  HD 7970 features 4 display outs - 1x DVI, 2xmini-DisplayPort and 1x HDMI .  Finally, the slide mentions the embargo release date - 9th January 2012 .  Needless to say, faked slides are nothing new for the rumour mill, so the information contained within this slide must be considered with caution .  However, most of the details contained are realistic, and the image of the shroud looks identical to the leaked pictures .  Source: OBR-hardware ARTICLE NAVIGATOR PREVIOUSLY Pogoplug launches Series 4, ads USB 3.0 connectivity and USM  UP NEXT Gigabyte X79-UD5 Review Wait! AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked by VR-Zone.com VR-Zone FORUMS PRICEWATCH VIDEOS CHINESE AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked Reported by Sub on Thursday, December 15 2011 4:17 am A slide purportedly to be part of the press deck, detailing Radeon HD 7970, has leaked online .  As previously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture with 32 CUs .  Tweet NEWS A slide purportedly detailing Radeon HD 7970 has leaked online .  The slide resembles AMD's standard presentation design, and is seemingly part of the press deck held .  Aspreviously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture .  The HD 7970 features 32 CU containing 2048 ALUs, clocked at 925 MHz .  This amounts to 3.5 TFLOPS (Single Precision).  TMUs are upped to 128, as expected .  However, ROPs remain at 32 compared to Cayman, which is odd considering the memory bus, as we have observed, is 384-bit .  Memory speed remains unchanged at 5.5 GHz, meaning a 50% boost in memory bandwidth .  The TDP is rated under 300W, while the idle power is incredibly only 3W .  This means a 8-pin + 6-pin power connector configuration .  HD 7970 features 4 display outs - 1x DVI, 2xmini-DisplayPort and 1x HDMI .  Finally, the slide mentions the embargo release date - 9th January 2012 .  Needless to say, faked slides are nothing new for the rumour mill, so the information contained within this slide must be considered with caution .  However, most of the details contained are realistic, and the image of the shroud looks identical to the leaked pictures . Quote: Originally Posted by mesirtoo Nice thread and info, crkpot - - may as well be considered the 'official one' for xxLV5500's .  I just ordered a 42LV5500 from Amazon (with their BD640 freebie through the 9th, and recently lowered bundle-price).  As a 'veteran' of the panel-lotto-war after two 37" VA-returns, I hope I won't be the first to report a non-IPS 42" LV5500.. . Have you had any luck using your enabled DVR-function on any other stick in usb1?  Or more info regards the Plus of enabling the THX-functions?  I'm keen on enabling control for local-dimming and using the DVR on-key, myself - - although I'd much appreciate a 'mini-FAQ' on using a Harmony/RCA/other remote to make changes within this service-menu (I checked provided link, but am unsure of " IN-start/IN-stop " reference - - just the 'EZ-ADJUST' applies for us, yes?).  Also, maybe someone would know the codes for an older Philips Pronto TS1000?  Thanks .  No luck on dvr yet, I found out from an Australian website you need at least 40gig usb drive for Time Machine to work and I don't have anything close to test with .  After enabling it in the service menu theres a new card on the HOME screen for DVR which I assume is to list your recorded programs. Local dimming is a must have option, if anything it's the one reason anyone would need to get into the service menu .  To explain the service menu, there's 3 different versions .  EZ ADJUST is all the non-critical model specific options that are as far as I've found pretty harmless .  I don't think there's anything in there that will brick a tv (but don't take my word for that).  The IN-START menu is more advanced and covers everything the EZ ADJUST menu has but in a more service tech layout with codes etc. Very little the normal person would need access too .  The IN-STOP is for factory reset and requires the same password as accessing the other menus .  Not sure about the Phillips Pronto, but if you can add the codes from the link it should work.

As of Feb 2012, I'd like to buy a small off-the-shelf HTPC for HDMI hookup to my Sony Bravia KDL 52W4100 HDTV but I'm reading about a lot problems with HDMI audio and complicated work arounds and patches depending on the equipment configuration .  I realize I can use HDMI or VGA or S-Video for picture plus RCA cables for audio, but I'd like to keep it all digital and uncluttered .  That's what HDMI is for, isn't it?  I'm open to any major computer brand running Windows 7 Home as long as it works right out of the box .  My uses are internet, Netflix, Blockbuster, Hulu, Itunes, adult video websites and OpenOffice word processing .  I prefer an HTPC with 4GB RAM, 1TB HD, wireless keyboard and mouse, DVD RW burner, ethernet, memory card readers, HDMI, USB 2 (& USB 3 if possible) and WI FI .  I've looked at specs for the new Mac Mini (with Bootcamp PC partition), HP Slimline, Gateway SX, Lenovo Revo, Dell Inspiron, Acer, Asus, E-Machines, etc. and they all seem to have HDMI audio problems with Sony Bravia, but it's too expensive a TV to replace so I'm building my home entertainment system around it .  I currently use a Sony PS3 for Blue Ray DVD playback and Netflix streaming, but the PS3 Explorer 6 browser is limited in streaming video from other websites and won't accept software upgrades other than from Sony and Netflix .  Can anyone recommend a ready made HTPC for under $1, 000 because I can't build my own .  Thanks.

I decided to leave Time Warner Cable and go with Dish .  I have the Dish on the house but the technician couldn't get it to work with my home entertainment system .  Time Warner allows their DVR to connect to the AV receiver by HDMI but not Dish .  With Dish I need to hook the TV directly to the Dish DVR and use RCA cables for sound instead of HDMI .  My concern is that I will loose sound quality .  Here is what I have: TV is a Pioneer Elite Pro-141FD AV Receiver is a Pioneer SC-25 Blu Ray Player LG BD390 Here is how I might have to hook it up .  Two HDMI from the TV, one to the DVR and one to the AV Receiver .  Then, RCA cables to the DVR for sound .  HDMI cable from the receiver to the Blu Ray .  Is there a better way to hook this up?  Thanks,

AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked by VR-Zone.com VR-Zone FORUMS PRICEWATCH VIDEOS CHINESE AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked Reported by Sub on Thursday, December 15 2011 4:17 am A slide purportedly to be part of the press deck, detailing Radeon HD 7970, has leaked online .  As previously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture with 32 CUs .  Tweet NEWS A slide purportedly detailing Radeon HD 7970 has leaked online .  The slide resembles AMD's standard presentation design, and is seemingly part of the press deck held .  Aspreviously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture .  The HD 7970 features 32 CU containing 2048 ALUs, clocked at 925 MHz .  This amounts to 3.5 TFLOPS (Single Precision).  TMUs are upped to 128, as expected .  However, ROPs remain at 32 compared to Cayman, which is odd considering the memory bus, as we have observed, is 384-bit .  Memory speed remains unchanged at 5.5 GHz, meaning a 50% boost in memory bandwidth .  The TDP is rated under 300W, while the idle power is incredibly only 3W .  This means a 8-pin + 6-pin power connector configuration .  HD 7970 features 4 display outs - 1x DVI, 2xmini-DisplayPort and 1x HDMI .  Finally, the slide mentions the embargo release date - 9th January 2012 .  Needless to say, faked slides are nothing new for the rumour mill, so the information contained within this slide must be considered with caution .  However, most of the details contained are realistic, and the image of the shroud looks identical to the leaked pictures .  Source: OBR-hardware ARTICLE NAVIGATOR PREVIOUSLY Pogoplug launches Series 4, ads USB 3.0 connectivity and USM  UP NEXT Gigabyte X79-UD5 Review Wait! AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked by VR-Zone.com VR-Zone FORUMS PRICEWATCH VIDEOS CHINESE AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked Reported by Sub on Thursday, December 15 2011 4:17 am A slide purportedly to be part of the press deck, detailing Radeon HD 7970, has leaked online .  As previously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture with 32 CUs .  Tweet NEWS A slide purportedly detailing Radeon HD 7970 has leaked online .  The slide resembles AMD's standard presentation design, and is seemingly part of the press deck held .  Aspreviously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture .  The HD 7970 features 32 CU containing 2048 ALUs, clocked at 925 MHz .  This amounts to 3.5 TFLOPS (Single Precision).  TMUs are upped to 128, as expected .  However, ROPs remain at 32 compared to Cayman, which is odd considering the memory bus, as we have observed, is 384-bit .  Memory speed remains unchanged at 5.5 GHz, meaning a 50% boost in memory bandwidth .  The TDP is rated under 300W, while the idle power is incredibly only 3W .  This means a 8-pin + 6-pin power connector configuration .  HD 7970 features 4 display outs - 1x DVI, 2xmini-DisplayPort and 1x HDMI .  Finally, the slide mentions the embargo release date - 9th January 2012 .  Needless to say, faked slides are nothing new for the rumour mill, so the information contained within this slide must be considered with caution .  However, most of the details contained are realistic, and the image of the shroud looks identical to the leaked pictures .  Source: OBR-hardware ARTICLE NAVIGATOR PREVIOUSLY Pogoplug launches Series 4, ads USB 3.0 connectivity and USM  UP NEXT Gigabyte X79-UD5 Review Wait! AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked by VR-Zone.com VR-Zone FORUMS PRICEWATCH VIDEOS CHINESE AMD Radeon HD 7970 specifications slide leaked Reported by Sub on Thursday, December 15 2011 4:17 am A slide purportedly to be part of the press deck, detailing Radeon HD 7970, has leaked online .  As previously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture with 32 CUs .  Tweet NEWS A slide purportedly detailing Radeon HD 7970 has leaked online .  The slide resembles AMD's standard presentation design, and is seemingly part of the press deck held .  Aspreviously rumoured, the HD 7970 features the GCN architecture .  The HD 7970 features 32 CU containing 2048 ALUs, clocked at 925 MHz .  This amounts to 3.5 TFLOPS (Single Precision).  TMUs are upped to 128, as expected .  However, ROPs remain at 32 compared to Cayman, which is odd considering the memory bus, as we have observed, is 384-bit .  Memory speed remains unchanged at 5.5 GHz, meaning a 50% boost in memory bandwidth .  The TDP is rated under 300W, while the idle power is incredibly only 3W .  This means a 8-pin + 6-pin power connector configuration .  HD 7970 features 4 display outs - 1x DVI, 2xmini-DisplayPort and 1x HDMI .  Finally, the slide mentions the embargo release date - 9th January 2012 .  Needless to say, faked slides are nothing new for the rumour mill, so the information contained within this slide must be considered with caution .  However, most of the details contained are realistic, and the image of the shroud looks identical to the leaked pictures .  Source: OBR-hardware ARTICLE NAVIGATOR PREVIOUSLY Pogoplug launches Series 4, ads USB 3.0 connectivity and USM  UP NEXT Gigabyte X79-UD5 Review Wait! Quote: Originally Posted by Kolgar As one of the " clueless " who compared all kinds of sets and then purchased a Samsung, I can tell you unequivocally that the HL-S in my home blows the store displays out of the water .  Perhaps it's the quality of my cables and feeds - for sure it has something to do with the fact that I made some simple adjustments to turn down the plasma-like brightness of this set - but I am experiencing virtually NO mosquito noise .  And the colors, while often " cartoony " in saturation at the stores, are now merely bright and natural .  Dramatic colors look dramatic; skin tones look like skin tones .  This set looks as good as or better than any comparably priced LCD, LCoS, or DLP I've seen .  I certainly don't mean to hijack this thread so I'll just end by saying I'm not going to tell you you're wrong - but I have a feeling your opinion may be based on less hands-on experience with these sets than my own .  You own and love your Samsung DLP set.. . so you're posting this in the Sony SXRD Owner's Thread WHY?  Why are you even here?  Go enjoy your DLP set and let the discussion go forward.

Quote: Originally Posted by anirbana You are right .  I don't use any enhancements or adjustments with MPC on the IN80 as it is pretty much perfect .  The HD65 is a good machine but it cannot match the quality of the IN80 or BenQ W5000 .  When you get your BenQ first look at what colour space option you have on the PJ .  If you have both RGB and RGB video (on a HDMI connection from HTPC) you can try the folloiwng .  1 .  With RGB - PC level - Use MPC with only check on overlay 2 .  With RGB Video Video levels - with MPC just watch it as it is and change black level or white level on PJ .  The quality of these new breed of budget 1080p PJS really amazes me .  Well, honestly, I have no idea what you're talking about, but I'll look into checking this when I actually have the projector in-hand.

Quote: Originally Posted by sparks81 My mistake .  As this is my first time on this thread, I was not aware of these problems. I worked for a dealer that sold the Pioneer and I was never aware of these problems described above .  I also have the BDP-94HD in another system .  No problems with either one except for the firmware updates .  It sounds like Pioneer has resolved these problems.. .hopefully!  have you used the analog outs yet?  If so, what do you think?  I have mine connected both ways to a Theta Digital Cassablanca III .  Analog sounds OK .  But, the digital connection reigns supreme.. .since the DACs in the Theta out perform the Wolfson DACs in the BDP-09 .  The 09 nonetheless, is still a good player .  The BDP-09FD's drive failures seemed to show up for everybody just around the 24 month mark as the 2 year Elite warranty expired.. .. .. I've got my BDP-09FD connected to a Pioneer VSX-59TXi receiver via analogs and think the 09FD is great for decoding the Blu-ray HD audio formats .  I don't use the 09 for music, I use my Pioneer DV-59AVi DVD player for music via the 59AVi's iLink connection to the 59TXi .  I just personally think the digital iLink connection sounds more dynamic and robust than the 09's analog for CDs and the 09 does not play SACD and DVD-Audio discs .  I really like the 09FD as a DVD player and think it may be the best DVD player I've ever seen .  The 59TXi has enough power to compensate for the volume loss from using analog inputs .  It's really weird how great the 09 sounds for movie and concert BDs but doesn't for CDs, maybe I am just spoiled by the 59AVi on music.. . Fred

I just personally think the digital iLink connection sounds more dynamic and robust than the 09's analog for CDs and the 09 does not play SACD and DVD-Audio discs .  I really like the 09FD as a DVD player and think it may be the best DVD player I've ever seen .  The 59TXi has enough power to compensate for the volume loss from using analog inputs .  It's really weird how great the 09 sounds for movie and concert BDs but doesn't for CDs, maybe I am just spoiled by the 59AVi on music.. . Fred

Wow SoftwireEngineer - those are some seriously nice speakers!  I appreciate all the tips .  I am currently using virbapods on my cd players and my rack unit weights a hefty 100 lbs (without gear) so I am not too concerned about additional vibrations as the thing is solid as a rock .  I will look into the cables you suggested but think that the whole polished CD thing is a bit much (no offence intended).  As for power conditioning, don't laugh but I am currently using a Monster HTS3500 which seems to meet my needs nicely for the time being .  Thanks again for the tips and feedback.

eSATA Doesn't Work!  Ok, Im at an impasse and I think Ive tried everything, so please someone come up with something new to help me!  I have a brand new HR21-700 running 0x1FE .  I read all the threads about this and I installed a WD10EACS into an Antec MX-1 VERIS enclosure .  Ive tried both the eSATA cable that came with the enclosure and a separately purchased SIIG eSATA cable .  Ive switched the cable ends .  Ive tried I think every variation of starting up  power off HR21, power on external for five minutes, then power up the HR21, a simple red button reboot and all the I can think of variations in between but no love . Much of this adjustability is different with the different AVR manufacturers .  I will use Onkyo as an example since I know their features the best .  Most Onkyo receivers have an adjustable manual EQ .  They also have tone controls that can be adjusted along with the manual EQ .  This is the part you need to remember .  If you're using Audyssey you cannot use the manual EQ .  You can however still use the tone control .  Which is bass and treble only .  No midrange control .  I don't think any modern AVRs have a mid control in the tone control .  Just bass and treble .  So with an Onkyo you could adjust the mid area with the manual EQ if you weren't using Audyssey.

Quote: Originally Posted by Carled On the flipside, none of those displays have what I would regard as acceptable scalers built in .  The 3007-HC has NO scaler whatsoever .  It will only accept native resolution (2560x1600 dual link DVI signal), so only an HTPC will work for BD playback .  Dell's newer 3008 has a scaler, but the 3008 has recently has been mysteriously pulled due to " technical issues."

Bought the 47LW5300 set on Black Friday from Walmart on Ship-to-store (just missed the Amazon deal).  Have it setup in a 2nd room as I need a larger entertainment center for it .  Thus far, I've tested 3D Harry Potter and 3D Tangled on it with no noticeable blooms and/or screen artifacts .  I went to the 47 over the 42 specifically due to the lack of local dimming on the 42 .  My tests have been in darkened room and while I probably need to turn the brightness/backlight down some, the darks have been much more easily discernable than my old 2D Vizio (non-LED).  I too have talked to the LG techs who assure me that the only difference between the -300 and -600 is the services .  The panels, timings, etc are all identical .  As my receiver (Onkyo TX-SR606) won't support the HDMI 1.4 (I bought dirt-cheap fry High-speed cables that work fine), I had my wife get me the Panny dmp-bdt310 for Xmas so that I can run audio through the receiver, and the video straight to the TV until I determine which new receiver I get to blow $$$on.

Quote: Originally Posted by Tom Weeden FYI: WMTV-DT is temporarily running fixed bit rate splits between channels 15-1 and 15-2 .  A TV dealer in the area reports that some Philips HD sets can't decode a picture on 15-1 when we are in " statistical multiplex " mode .  We have the big guns (the company we bought the equipment from, that is) working on this to see if it's on our end or if Philips HD sets need a software upgrade .  I was told that Philips standard-definition digital TVs were fine on both 15-1 and 15-2 .  My money is on the Philips HD sets not working correctly .  I hate to say that, since I work for Philips (not the division that makes consumer electronics).  I've had to deal with 20" LCD computer monitors that had problems. We couldn't convince them there was a problem .  A newer model comes out and, bam, problem gone .  Quote: If anyone had problems seeing 15-1 in the last week (with 15-2 coming in OK), please let me know in case there are other receivers acting up .  I haven't had my two STBs on for a long time .  Any OTA stuff I need I do via the PeeCee MyHD card that I have .  It has zero problems with the previous config .  The STB isn't having a problem at the moment

Please accept my apology, I must admit I have not searched this entire thread for my issue .  It may be that it just is what it is .  My HDPVR seems to be working great .  My main issue is when I record shows, I get huge black bars on the top and bottom of the resulting .ts file .  When I just watch the show on the TV, it looks fine .  The recordings are bordering on unusable because the video is such a small strip in the middle of the screen .  I have searched high and low for some possible settings, but cannot find any .  I'm also having issues out of the Blaster config, but that issue can be addressed later .  The HDPVR is connected to a DirecTV HR-20 DVR via component cables .  If more information is needed to help me address this issue, please let me know .  Any help is certainly appreciated .  Steve PS .  The areas highlighted in red in the attached jpg are what I am referring to.

The ONLY thing I'm using a VCR for now is to copy tapes over to my PC, where I will burn them to DVD (Doing Star Wars Episode 4 right now.) My PC has a Hauppage WinPVR250 that does real-time MPEG encoding .  I use that to record (what doesn't get recorded on the DVR510 - sometimes I will record from the 510).

Quote: Originally Posted by MichaelLAX I have two DirecTiVo HD HR10-250s and two DirecTV HD HR20-700s .  I find the situation of recording from the newer HR20-700 even better than the older model .  In the older model, you had to manually change the resolution to 480i so that you could get a video signal out of the S-Video port, and then you manually had to change it back to 1080i to watch it in that resolution on your HDTV after recording .  Now the HR20-700 outputs a video signal from all of the Video ports even when the HDMI is sending 1080i to the HDTV .  I find that the video signal is anamorphic either when I record it to my Panny VHS/DVD Recorder (although I have to record it on a DVD-RW and use my computer to fix the aspect ratio setting on the resulting DVD-R) and on my ADS Tech Instant DVD (for Mac) MPEG-2 digitizer box (which I use when I want to edit down the resulting digitized content before I burn it to a DVD or convert it to H.264 for my Apple TV).  I am very happy now that I can DVD record (or digitize) all of the new 16x9 HD channels that DirecTV has to offer.. . Good luck!  Thanks for your reply .  I like the fact that you don't have to change the resolution .  You said: " I find that the video signal is anamorphic either when I record it to my Panny VHS/DVD Recorder (although I have to record it on a DVD-RW and use my computer to fix the aspect ratio setting on the resulting DVD-R) " .  I assume that you use ifoedit or something similar to change the aspect flags from 4:3 to 16:9 .  I also have a Panasonic DVD/HD recorder for which I have to do the same thing .  The nice thing about the two Sony DVD recorders I listed is that you don't have to do that .  Anyone on the forum burning DVDs from the HR20 or HR21 to the Sony DVD recorders I listed?

Quote: Originally Posted by MichaelLAX I have two DirecTiVo HD HR10-250s and two DirecTV HD HR20-700s .  I find the situation of recording from the newer HR20-700 even better than the older model .  In the older model, you had to manually change the resolution to 480i so that you could get a video signal out of the S-Video port, and then you manually had to change it back to 1080i to watch it in that resolution on your HDTV after recording .  Now the HR20-700 outputs a video signal from all of the Video ports even when the HDMI is sending 1080i to the HDTV .  I find that the video signal is anamorphic either when I record it to my Panny VHS/DVD Recorder (although I have to record it on a DVD-RW and use my computer to fix the aspect ratio setting on the resulting DVD-R) and on my ADS Tech Instant DVD (for Mac) MPEG-2 digitizer box (which I use when I want to edit down the resulting digitized content before I burn it to a DVD or convert it to H.264 for my Apple TV).  I am very happy now that I can DVD record (or digitize) all of the new 16x9 HD channels that DirecTV has to offer.. . Good luck!  Thanks for your reply .  I like the fact that you don't have to change the resolution . Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech I tried to record off a Motorola 6400 that said the firewire was " enabled=yes ", " active=no " That's the expected status .  It'll work, provided that the DVHS VCR is tuned to the correct input (D-1, or D-2, or D-3, etc) and the 5c flag isn't set to Copy-Once or Copy-Never .  (PC's and the Mits DVHS VCRs can't record Copy-Once material) active=no just means that it wasn't in use at that moment .  Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech I followed the instructions for the 2000U and made a test recording onto D-VHS .  But when I tried to play it back through the T165, there was nothing .  Comcast has since replaced that box with a Pace model RGN-110 box.. . tried to record off it and it didn't work .  There's any number of mistakes that could have occurred here.. .You need to monitor the output of the firewire in realtime, to make sure that the DVHS is getting anything at all .  Have one firewire cable going from the cable box to the DVHS VCR, and another firewire cable going from the DVHS VCR to the T165 .  Connect the T165 to your TV (tune the T165 to view the DVHS).  This will let you know if a signal is reaching the DVHS .  Quote: Originally Posted by tabrech Some guys also told me the Mitsubishi won't work with a firewire cable boxes .  I've used the Mits 1100u quite a few times with my Motorola DCH3416 .  I can't recall if I've tried to use my Mits 2000u with my cable box, but I'd be really surprised if it didn't also work flawlessly (I'll try to run a test in the next day or so).  The Mits DVHS VCR's are not 5c compliant, so you can only record material which is flagged Copy-Freely .  The JVC DVHS VCR's are 5c compliant and let you record anything flagged Copy-Freely or Copy-Once.

I currently have a pair of Kef Q70 tower speakers as my fronts, Kef Q95C center channel, cheap Energy rears and an M&K MX-125 Mark II subwoofer .  I'm looking to get a new HD TV and will have to replace the speakers due to space issues .  I've been looking to get a set of Def Tech ProCinema fronts, center and surrounds .  I've been happy with my M&K sub but was considering replacing it as well .  The general consensus I've read was don't buy the Def Tech sub and instead get an SVS sub .  I'd be looking at an SVS cylinder PC-Plus sub, not sure which particular model .  I don't have any place to listen to an SVS sub .  I was wondering if anyone has had a chance to listen to or replaced an M&K sub with an SVS and would have an opinion about how they are different and which one they like .  My room is pretty large at 20'W x 30'L x 10'H and has hardwood floors .  I'm about 80% home theatre (movies and TV), 10% gaming and 10% music .  I've been happy with my M&K sub so far .  It can really rattle my room .  My only complaint is sometimes there is too much bass between the Kefs and the sub and sometimes it can get a bit boomy but thats something that could probably be fine tuned.

Forget any other device .  Calibration is valid only for BluRay Player since there some standarts in the mastering of the BluRay Movies we are targeting .  Satelite Signal, TV Signal, Games .  nonone is following well any standard .  (Exept the Signal Standatd) Multiple conversion are made by the channels when you are getting the singal .  For example, watch the same TV Channel all day (with your calibrated tv using a Blu-Ray Source), do you see the same skintones during the day?  It's imposible to have the same skintones .  If you are watching NTSC DVD Movies, the color primaries are different from the HD Rec .  709 Blu-Ray Movies, you need different settings for that also.

Question for the 876 owners out there.. .. .. . I have an 876 that Ive had for about a year and a half or so .  I have a cable box and ps3 and sony bluray player hooked up to it via HDMI .  I have a 5.1 speaker array connected (klipsch speakers).. .. . Ive always noticed that the audible volume is always higher when watching tv or playing a ps3 game like Call of duty .  The volume setting on the unit in these cases can be set around -30db .  However, when I play a movie, I need to turn the volume up to about -12db .  which seems like its a pretty high volume setting for the actual volume levels im hearing .  Its been like this since I have had the receiver, but I never really bothered to ask anyone if its correct or not .  So.. .. .. does this sound normal??  or is it possible that I do not have something set up correctly on the reciever or the ps3 or bluray player.. .. .. Thanks all for the great reading in this post!!!!!

Quote: Originally Posted by Digital Rules You'll need to add a VHF-HI antenna for ABC, & PBS .  (Winegard YA-1713 or Antennacraft Y10-7-13) Combining the existing VHF antenna with the 91XG by way of the 7777 should serve the purpose .  Just make sure to set the internal switch on the pre-amp to, " separates. " Also, adjusting the antenna height can make a difference .  There are sweet spots, even with outdoor antennas .  Make sure to check the cabling connections for corrosion, etc. 10+ year old cabling, outdoors and of unknown type could certainly be part of the problem.

Quote: Originally Posted by Digital Rules You'll need to add a VHF-HI antenna for ABC, & PBS .  (Winegard YA-1713 or Antennacraft Y10-7-13) Combining the existing VHF antenna with the 91XG by way of the 7777 should serve the purpose .  Just make sure to set the internal switch on the pre-amp to, " separates. " Also, adjusting the antenna height can make a difference .  There are sweet spots, even with outdoor antennas .  Make sure to check the cabling connections for corrosion, etc. 10+ year old cabling, outdoors and of unknown type could certainly be part of the problem.

Quote: Originally Posted by koffas They take a CR2025 lithium battery .  I got a 5-pack through Amazon ($2.79 including shipping).  http://www.amazon.com/Maxell-Micro-L.. ./dp/B0002TJGRW Buy an 100-pack for 10 Bucks incl .  shipping on ebay .  http://cgi.ebay.com/100-x-CR2025-DL2.. .item4aa139aafd

I have a 56" JVC connected to my Onkyo A/V receiver and a Motorola cable box via HDMI .  Sometimes when changing channels we see the green screen, but we still get audio .  Changing channels from standard def to hi-def usually causes a reset HDMI handshake during the resolution change and fixes the problem, otherwise we power cycle everything and all is fine .  It happens periodically, but is not enough of a pain to do anything drastic.

I have a question for any previous DILA owners .  I have the P61R1U, It is my third DILA set .  I had the HD61Z575 and the HD56G886 previously .  My set seems substantially darker than the other 2 sets I had .  It is very noticeable to me, especially during movies .  Daytime scenes look almost as if they should be nightime scenes .  It is the same from my stb and oppo dvd player .  I am just curious if any other previous DILA owners feel this set is darker than the others .  I use the hdmi connections, but have hooked up componant cables with no difference.

Anaxagoras said: And like TaoTeJared I had a few wacky overexposures - about 6 out of 750 shots .  Thank god!  (Well not really) but I was starting to think I was going mad with that .  I wouldn't consider a D90 at this point unless you are fine upgrading again in a year .  I haven't seen many on ebay go for less than $650 and the tech is 6 years old .  Tamron has some good Super zoom lenses you may want to consider as well .  It seems you were focused on f2.8 glass, but 60% of your shooting will be done at f/8 or higher .  You could go with any decent super-zoom or the 18-105 and pick up a older 50mm 1.8 for portraits when you want bokeh .  Just a note on the " 4-year extended warranty " - if you are buying new, I personally wouldn't bother .  Nikon will cover everything for a few years, and the D7000 is built very well .  It is rare that anything goes bad past the first year and honestly in 4 years, you will probably be looking to upgrade .  Heavy use can add to the chance, but you don't sound like you will be doing 100k+ photos a year .  That might save you some $$for a lens or adding a 50mm as well.

Quote: Originally Posted by mesirtoo Nice thread and info, crkpot - - may as well be considered the 'official one' for xxLV5500's .  I just ordered a 42LV5500 from Amazon (with their BD640 freebie through the 9th, and recently lowered bundle-price).  As a 'veteran' of the panel-lotto-war after two 37" VA-returns, I hope I won't be the first to report a non-IPS 42" LV5500.. . Have you had any luck using your enabled DVR-function on any other stick in usb1?  Or more info regards the Plus of enabling the THX-functions?  I'm keen on enabling control for local-dimming and using the DVR on-key, myself - - although I'd much appreciate a 'mini-FAQ' on using a Harmony/RCA/other remote to make changes within this service-menu (I checked provided link, but am unsure of " IN-start/IN-stop " reference - - just the 'EZ-ADJUST' applies for us, yes?).  Also, maybe someone would know the codes for an older Philips Pronto TS1000?  Thanks .  No luck on dvr yet, I found out from an Australian website you need at least 40gig usb drive for Time Machine to work and I don't have anything close to test with .  After enabling it in the service menu theres a new card on the HOME screen for DVR which I assume is to list your recorded programs. Local dimming is a must have option, if anything it's the one reason anyone would need to get into the service menu .  To explain the service menu, there's 3 different versions .  EZ ADJUST is all the non-critical model specific options that are as far as I've found pretty harmless .  I don't think there's anything in there that will brick a tv (but don't take my word for that).  The IN-START menu is more advanced and covers everything the EZ ADJUST menu has but in a more service tech layout with codes etc. Very little the normal person would need access too .  The IN-STOP is for factory reset and requires the same password as accessing the other menus .  Not sure about the Phillips Pronto, but if you can add the codes from the link it should work.

Quote: Originally Posted by Elpee I like the fact " US Based support - No jobs overseas ", but it doesn't mean all .  Still waiting the confirmation of HD audio passthru (true HD and DTS-HD MA) before I pull the trigger on either this or A-200 .  They are same price .  From what I hear, Nixeus wanted to have to have it actually made here in the USA, but they could not find anyone to design it or actually make it so they could retail it for $199 .  But they do tell me that the support side of it will always be handled by English speraking live people in the USA, they believe its something that few other mediaplayer makers (eg PCH) can compete with + the 2 year warranty of course, for many people thats a real biggie .  Regards, Teddy

Quote: Originally Posted by thugnegro hey guys im currently looking for and upgrade of my system .  but i cant decide which one to go for .  A used Klipsch High-End 5.1 Speaker System a guy is selling me or a new Pioneer SP-PK21BS .  the Klipsch High-End 5.1 Speaker System has: 2-Klipsch RF-15 Reference Series 2-Klipsch RS-25 Rear Speakers 1-Klipsch RC-25 Reference Series Center 1-Klipsch RPW-10 Reference Series All of this for 250 the Pioneer SP-PK21BS .  is 399 i know the Klipsch are a lil old and the pioneer are gonna be new .  So i just wanna know even when the Klipsch are old would it be a smart to buy them at that price?  or woul it be better to go for the pioneer?  Unless the speakers are damaged I would pay $250 for the Klipsch because that sounds like a really good deal, but fwiw, that isn't considered a Klipsch " High end system. " Later on if you wanted to upgrade your mains to a Klipsch high end system you could use some of those other speakers in the mix .  Good Luck and welcome to the forum.

Wanted to say thanks for the fantastic guide and have enjoyed all of the great information from this community .  I have built a couple Frankenstein htpc machines from old salvaged parts from my work, but this will be the first dedicated HTPC machine .  Please let me know how these specs look for a family room HTPC (WAF & DAF very important): Case: Habey EMC-600B Optical: None - Everything is on the NAS and use network quad core for ripping/transcoding Mobo: ASRock H67M-ITX LGA 1155 Intel H67 N82E16813157238 CPU: I3 2100 Boot Hd: OCZ Solid 3 60GB Secondary Hd: 250gb 2.5 hd (salvage) I have 5tb on the NAS so just wanted a little more than the boot os local .  Memory: 2gb 1066 (salvage) I know this is low, but I already have it, plus with a fast SSD you don't pay that much of a penalty for page file swapping .  Is this ok, or should I spend the $25 and go for 4gb 1333?  Cable: Networked bridged Ceton infitivi4 2 channels - 1gb lan Remote: This is one of my biggest concerns, suggestions appreciated .  On my basement HTPC I am using/testing 4 remotes: Harmony SST-659 best for turning on/off TV/Receiver/htpc, only so so for WMC navigation .  Lenovo N5902 maybe best all around but still lacking for control of other devices and quick access to forward/reverse, ease of use when not staring at remote .  Not good for speed watching of football games .  Iphone - logitech touch mouse best for keyboard entry and mouse based navigation, poor for WMC control .  Iphone Boxee remote control - great for boxee no use for wmc .  VRC-1100 bad for text entry, tivo remote type shape and layout probably make it best for overall wmc navigation .  IR seems very sensitive about aiming directly at sensor .  This will primarily be for watching TV, NAS movie library, netflix and hulu .  Not a fan of home 3D - yet.

Quote: Originally Posted by haebby Apology if this was already answered in detail.. . Can someone confirm that HD video files captured from a Canon HV20 can be played back properly via the 4100 and/or the 5100?  I'm using Sony Vegas Studio Platinum to capture the files .  Also - once I edited my HD videos - what format should I save them in (using Sony Vegas Studio) so that they can be played back at the highest quality possible via the 4100/5100?  Thanks!  My HV20 .m2t, captured by HDVSplit, ran smoothly on 4100SH either directly from the internal hard drive, attached USB drive, or wired streaming .  I have failed on setting up wireless connection, so no wireless streaming result so far .  The saved format after editing in Sony Vegas depends on your convenience and your starting format (60i/24p).  Some would use a common codec like H264 (basic) or WMV for final rendering.. . For me, I left it as .m2t.

As of Feb 2012, I'd like to buy a small off-the-shelf HTPC for HDMI hookup to my Sony Bravia KDL 52W4100 HDTV but I'm reading about a lot problems with HDMI audio and complicated work arounds and patches depending on the equipment configuration .  I realize I can use HDMI or VGA or S-Video for picture plus RCA cables for audio, but I'd like to keep it all digital and uncluttered .  That's what HDMI is for, isn't it?  I'm open to any major computer brand running Windows 7 Home as long as it works right out of the box .  My uses are internet, Netflix, Blockbuster, Hulu, Itunes, adult video websites and OpenOffice word processing .  I prefer an HTPC with 4GB RAM, 1TB HD, wireless keyboard and mouse, DVD RW burner, ethernet, memory card readers, HDMI, USB 2 (& USB 3 if possible) and WI FI .  I've looked at specs for the new Mac Mini (with Bootcamp PC partition), HP Slimline, Gateway SX, Lenovo Revo, Dell Inspiron, Acer, Asus, E-Machines, etc. and they all seem to have HDMI audio problems with Sony Bravia, but it's too expensive a TV to replace so I'm building my home entertainment system around it .  I currently use a Sony PS3 for Blue Ray DVD playback and Netflix streaming, but the PS3 Explorer 6 browser is limited in streaming video from other websites and won't accept software upgrades other than from Sony and Netflix .  Can anyone recommend a ready made HTPC for under $1, 000 because I can't build my own .  Thanks.

Can anyone recommend a ready made HTPC for under $1, 000 because I can't build my own .  Thanks.

I decided to leave Time Warner Cable and go with Dish .  I have the Dish on the house but the technician couldn't get it to work with my home entertainment system .  Time Warner allows their DVR to connect to the AV receiver by HDMI but not Dish .  With Dish I need to hook the TV directly to the Dish DVR and use RCA cables for sound instead of HDMI .  My concern is that I will loose sound quality .  Here is what I have: TV is a Pioneer Elite Pro-141FD AV Receiver is a Pioneer SC-25 Blu Ray Player LG BD390 Here is how I might have to hook it up .  Two HDMI from the TV, one to the DVR and one to the AV Receiver .  Then, RCA cables to the DVR for sound .  HDMI cable from the receiver to the Blu Ray .  Is there a better way to hook this up?  Thanks,

Quote: Originally Posted by Jamie R .  Guys I had a problem very similar to this!!!!!  Annoyed the hell out of me!!!  Never through a code and finnally through one after I had at the Ford Dealership!!  Well my car would have like a miss or hesitation like low speeds in town going between red lights .  From behind at the tail pipes the car would sound like it would have a miss or stumble under partial throttle and as soon as I would give it some gas the car would run fine .  At crusing speeds like 65 - 70 it would do this also just not as pronounced .  Well my problem turned out to be the DPFE Sensor .  The DPFE Sensor is located on the back of the intake and has two rubber hoses going into it .  The two hoses go to the EGR pipe that comes off the exhaust pipe .  Try the DPFE Sensor and it might be your problem .  Jamie R .  '01 Silver Cobra on the Cover of MM&FF's August '07 Issue That would make alot of sense .  Especially since when I disconnect the battery for a while it will run fine for a little while then it starts doing it again .  This would mean that the computer is re-learning that problem and making it hesitate and stumble again .  When I got my car tuned it ran fine for a long time and then it started doing this exact thing as you described .  Then I changed the fuel filter, plugs, and cleaned the MAF .  It ran fine for a few weeks but now its doing it again and its just getting worse and worse .  I'm ready to come unglued .  Here is my dilema in respone to what you posted .  What if you dont have any of that crap anymore?  I deleted my EGR and all that stuff that went with it .  Its all turned off in my tune and I'm not throwing any codes On a side note: The car runs fine under FULL acceleration .  It only does this under partial acceleration .  I really just need to get it on the dyno with MY tuner and datalog it and see if we cant straighten it out .  But I dont have the money or time right now .  So I am stuck trying to figure it out myself until the money is there.

Almost finished putting together a new system .  I've settled on L/R: Studio 20's C: CC-590 Rears will be in-ceiling, I will probably go with something from the PV line .  Sub will come in a couple months .  A few questions please: 1) I haven't heard the CC590 in person - dealers around here only have the SE center .  With the Studio 20's as fronts, would the 490 be fine, or the step up to the 590 is really worth the difference in cost?  FWIW the SE (490 equivalent I believe) sounded good to me, if slightly boxy .  2) Are the stands made by Paradigm for the Studio 20's strongly recommended, or have folks had good luck with other, 3rd party stands?  3) I listened to Elite, Integra, and Anthem for receivers, and IMO the Anthem was sooo much better with these speakers (not terribly surprising).  The Anthem did not have ARC run, it just simply sounded great - but, I really wanted AirPlay built in .  The MRX500 would be really stretching the budget, and adding an Apple TV adds more pain .  Assuming I can't swing the MRX-500, what would be a recommendation for something with similar 'sound' to Anthem, that does have AirPlay?  I was thinking Yamaha .  4) If you guys had to build out your system over a couple months, which of these would you do to start with: Fronts/surrounds and phantom center, no sub Fronts and center, no surrounds/sub Fronts and sub, phantom center, no surrounds Really excited about the Studio 20's, they really blew the doors off everything else for HT I listened to .  Unfortunately my budget has doubled in the last 2 weeks and it will still require piecing out to get everything I want, damn this is expensive.

Quote: Originally Posted by B&W700guy Penn, any news?  Have you sold the T175?  Nope but Im not advertising it anywhere any more .  Its value might be dropping like a rock .  I do not have access to Audiogon's blue book prices to compare .  I always have a room I can upgrade with it, My office has the V663 in it and maybe I will move that to a box and put the NAD T-175 in there .  I even considered using it just as a volume control for my active setup .  The DCX is a pro gain setup and If I was to do it properly I need volume controls after it but right now I just have amps (Sunfire and Outlaw) they have no volume controls .  I could do Pre/pro -> DCX2496 -> analog in to Pre/pro -> amps .  Then I can set the proper gain structure and even further reduce any possible noise in the DAC of the DCX.

The DCX is a pro gain setup and If I was to do it properly I need volume controls after it but right now I just have amps (Sunfire and Outlaw) they have no volume controls .  I could do Pre/pro -> DCX2496 -> analog in to Pre/pro -> amps .  Then I can set the proper gain structure and even further reduce any possible noise in the DAC of the DCX.

Sound Thinking -> ADS L1090s first series - advice please New Account Validation Help  Enter Chat Here Help  Search  Members  Calendar Welcome Guest (Log In | Register) Resend Validation Email Sound Thinking->Gear->Speakers  ADS L1090s first series - advice please Track this topic | Email this topic | Print this topic thedelihaus Posted: October 16, 2006 04:32 pm The Black Dahlquist Group: Moderator Posts: 2615 Member No.: 9 Joined: June 30, 2006 Got a lead on some ADS L1090s, first series, I believe .  The seller sounds like an excellent fella, by the way .  Always a plus .  I prefer dealing with good people - too many unkind folk out there quickly ready to give you grief .  I know that 810s are selling for high lately, for $325 to $385, and occasionally in the $400 and $600 range .  I also know those stunning 1230s I posted a few days ago couldn't sell for $200 (!!!), and that near-cherry pair of 'em sold for just over $400 .  What's the going rate for these do you feel?  One speaker is missing one of it's metal grill, the cabs have lots of little scratches, and some veneer glued to one to cover some bunged mounting holes .  I want to be fair with the seller .  But I also want to be smart with any speaker investment I get .  The woofer drivers are a rare size for ADS - 6.5 " (csalled 7s).  Do these drivers (woofers) look original?  I've never seen the 1090s, so I'm unsure .  How do these sound compared to ADS L810s?  And, lastly, what was the biggest difference between the 1090s and the L1090 IIs? I originally thought the VC covers were not original but I think they are after looking at the picture .  Maybe $200 would be a good price as long as they work properly .  I've seen grills on eBay before but you'll have to be patient to find another one .  Attached Image (Click thumbnail to expand) dingus Posted: October 16, 2006 05:27 pm How can people be so cruel?  Group: Admin Posts: 6600 Member No.: 3 Joined: June 29, 2006 the woofers look fine to me .  never heard the 1090's but my guess is they would be a step up from the 810 .  as for how they compare to the L-1090's, guessing again, i doubt there is any significant sonic difference .  the pair you have a line on look to be in very condition .  if the price is low enough, in a worst case scenario you could flip them for a nice profit .  ------------------- - AR MGC-1, M&K V-B1, Pioneer VSX 47TX, Oppo BDP-83, Squeezebox v3, Vortexbox Appliance .  thedelihaus Posted: October 16, 2006 05:27 pm The Black Dahlquist Group: Moderator Posts: 2615 Member No.: 9 Joined: June 30, 2006 Price is $200 or best offer - the cabs are scratched up lots though - hard to see in the pic .  I don't need another pair of speakers, but since they are fairly close, I could let a few pieces go to raise the cash for them if I really wanted.. . Here are the spread sheet picture calibration tables for the LG 42LD550 I own .  I will add tables for each input I have adjusted .  This is a lot of work and hours of run time and adjusting using a Spyder 3 Pro as well as the Avia DVD, and final viewing using several personal reference DVDs, " Seabiscuit " being a favorite for it's color balance and mono chrome picture content .  I feel confident that these settings should work for the xxLD520 as well .  I have settings for normal viewing in daylight conditions, night time, and for HDMI DVD inputs, a warm setting, as well as a bit cooler than 6500K settings for people like my wife who prefer that picture color temperature .  Again, I will add the tables as I complete them so check back as I edit and add them .  EDIT: See next post #61
